title: 25+ Years Of Logging Every Film I Watch
author: GRDCS1980
description:
Tl;dr at the bottom

So, I’ve been obsessively logging every* film I’ve watched from September 1999 (when I was 19) all the way to today.

This has come up a handful of times in various film-related threads here on Reddit and several Redditors have expressed an interest in seeing the whole log. 

So, I’m posting it now, for your entertainment, astonishment, bafflement, ridicule, etc.

To try and preempt some potential questions:

There is a 20 month gap between the end of Feb 2001 and October 2003. During this period, I switched from pen and paper to an Excel document. But then the laptop I was keeping it on crashed, irrevocably, and since I was too dumb to have kept a back up, those 20 months are lost forever.

The most films I ever watched in a single day (not counting short films) is 10, on 8th May 2021.

The most films I ever watched in a single month is 89, in October 2023.

The most films I ever watched in a single year is 737, in 2023.

The longest unbroken streak of days is 590 days, between 30th July 2022 and 10th March 2024, where I watched 1,159 films in those 590 days.

Since the start of 2020, I’ve been logging on Letterboxd as well as my pen and paper log. I’m planning to work backward and get everything logged in LB going back to Sept 1999, but that’s a big job and I don’t know when I’ll find the time to do it.

Link to my LB is below, but I should warn you in advance, I literally only use it as a logging tool. I don’t follow back, I don’t write reviews, I sometimes put lists together for various purposes, but it’s almost exclusively for logging, so there really isn’t much point in following me, but you are welcome to do so if you wish.

https://boxd.it/IRhX


Tl;dr - I’ve been logging every* film I watch since September 1999. I’ve mentioned this a handful of times in various film-related Reddit threads and people have encouraged me to post the entire log, so now I am, for your entertainment, bafflement, ridicule, whatever.

*I’m missing a 20 month chunk due to my own stupidity, so it’s not quite “every” film.

title: What exactly are these? Vintage DVDs?
author: AsheDogg
description:
I found these in the dumpster while I was taking out trash, I know they are like vintage movies but not exactly sure what they are. Definitely before my time lol, it’s like 30-40 of them I took them out because they look to cool to be in the dump!
I also noticed none of them are opened as well.

comments.comment: They are CED discs. If you were to open one up, you would find a disc that looks like a record, but has smaller and more dense grooves. RCA started developing them in the early 70’s. By the time they hit the market in the late 70’s, they had to compete with VHS and Betamax, which were already leading in the format wars. These disc were pretty much phased out by the mid-80’s.
Also worth noting is that you don’t open these up to play them. You would stick them in a CED player, which would pull the disc out. I’ve never used one, but theoretically, I know how it works.
I think technology connections has a video on YouTube about this. I’ll try and find it. Or maybe it was mentions of this style of disc media when discussing laser disc

Ok well I’m glad I didn’t try to pry them open lol 
But thanks I was thinking they were what the theaters back in the day used for showing movies.
I’ll probably hang them as posters they look vintage and cool
Hey OP this is a good haul. Look up on ebay. Some going for 20+ dollars each

My family used to go to the video store, rent the machine that played those and a couple of movies.. this was late 70s. It was kind of the video equivalent of 8-tracks.

In the early 80s, we used to rent laser discs and a player. Eventually, we got a VCR.

We also had a Pong console (pre-Atari) hooked up to the 13" B&W TV in the enclosed porch.

and yes, I'm 100 years old

There aren't a lot of collectors of these left, but they're pretty avid. I had a friend who collected analog video discs and had a player (we watched Rocky on it, and the disc had to be flipped halfway through). He typically bought multiple copies of his favorite films whenever he found them, so if you're interested in selling these you'll probably find some buyers.
Vintage DVDs. I like that.
Some classic movies here. Have to have some collective value
Video discs

It’s a good idea because you don’t touch the disc but when you insert it you have this huge empty shell to deal with. I guess you can display the art like a “now showing” sign. They’re big, heavy, should be stored upright and typically the picture sucks. Source: I’m an idiot who owns a CED player.

We had this player and probably 30 or so movies. RCA ended up bankrupting itself when they released this. The company was so focused on a single tech vision for this format. Unfortunately that tech became obsolete immediately upon public release. RCA killed itself.
If there’s an iconic horror movie there (Friday the 13th, The Thing, etc) then collectors are interested but usually they just gather dust. I’ve yet to find a working player.

These are a home media format from the early to late 80s known as the CED Videodisc. They were made by RCA and began production in the 1950s, yet were so troubled that they wouldn't be "finished" until the early 80s. Just imagine a record, but with video and sound instead of just sound.

Technology Connections did a really good and in-depth video series. [Here](https://m.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3Hh3QDzcWoD6_bvb1dTwMEPuJt1p05DC) is the best playlist I could find with all the videos, but it seems the creator added 4 random videos at the end. Oh well, it still has all the CED videos.

Have you seen the Miyazaki films? *Spirited Away* and *Nausicaa* are some of my favorites. They are beautifully animated and incredibly complex. *Fantastic Planet* is another cool animation, this one from the 70s. 

*Coherence* and *Man from Earth* are some good head scratchers and incredibly low budget.

*2001: A Space Odyssey* is slow and weird, but visually stunning. 

Coen Brother's films, especially *O Brother Where Art Thou* are hilarious, and kind of surreal.

*Amelie* , *Harold and Maude* and *Everything is Illuminated* are all unique, funny, and a bit profound  

Make an effort to see and many different genres, from countries, and time periods.  There's good stuff to be found everywhere. Be open to the classics, too, even corny and campy things can have some gems.


Also, be aware that some of the other movies being recommended are some incredibly violent and disturbing ones. Some of them are still very good, but remember that a movie doesnt need to shock. I overlooked 'tame' movies for too long

But, being new to movies, I'd suggest sitting some of those out for now, I think you'll appreciate them more later.

I think if you watch a movie specifically to have your mind blown and your life changed, chances are neither of those things are going to happen and you're going to ask yourself what the big deal is with those movies, or what's wrong with me? Movies DO change lives and DO blow minds, but the movie that may change YOUR life may wind up being something very few people would put on this list. It could be Stan Brakhage's "Mothlight." Or  Kenji Mizoguchi's "Sansho the Bailiff." Or Satjiyat Ray's "Prather Panchali" series. Or Jaques Tati's "Playtime."

And honestly, the effect your looking for may not come in your teens or twenties, it may only come when you're much older and after you've seen a lot of great films. But keep looking and keep watching, and most importantly,  keep an open mind!

I started where you were when I was 14 or so. I just decided I wanted to learn about “old movies” which at that time were movies from the 1930s through 1950s that still aired on tv all the time. Couldn’t rent videos, no internet, so I read a lot of books about old Hollywood and watched for movies to come on so I could watch them. And just built out from there, mostly around actors and actresses I liked.

At the same time I started going to movies currently out every chance I got. The first time I identified a current movie doing something I’d seen in an old movie I was tickled to death. Being able to trace trends and styles and see when a newer director is doing a homage to something older is one of the pleasures of knowing about movies.

Disclaimer: it is NOT a pleasant movie, and you should probably watch it with an adult.  It's got graphic depictions of sex and drug use, but it is a pretty good portrayal of the depths of depravity people get into when drugs take a hold of their lives. The only thing INNACURATE about it, is you're far more likely to see young women turn to straight prostitution than doing amateur porn to pay for their habit, so really, the truth is worse than fiction.

I mean, the OG greatest movie, Citizen Kane. 

Now I know this is at/ ear the top of every list of best ever, and that can make some people think it’s over rated.

I will tell you, it ain’t. It’s a non linear biased narrative of a man as seen by the people in his life. What changes in who he is and what doesn’t change, from age 8-80, the whole movie is trying to discover “Who is Charles Foster Kane” and…it gives you some idea, certainly more than the other characters. 

But beyond that the look, the LOOK!! It set the template for film noir as it was developing. The (apparent)  size and scale of the sets is incredible, the makeup effects look great today, and the speed that it moves through the story is so fast, but never confusing. 

I really recommend watching it once as is and then again soon after with the Roger Ebert commentary track. This movie is 10 years ahead of everything else at the time (1941) and feels modern today. 

From there, you can check out writer and director’s and actors who were influenced by Citizen Kane. 

Welcome to a large world, kid. It’s a fun ride.

You remind me of myself at your age. My first real introduction to cinema was 
A Clockwork Orange (Kubrick, 1971). I saw that the summer after I graduated sixth grade and it changed me. I would 1000% recommend that. On that note, here’s an incomplete list that I’m sure you’ll love:

1: A Clockwork Orange (Kubrick, 1971). Yes, I already mentioned it but I cannot recommend this one enough. Kubrick is arguably thee most important modern director, and this one is his magnum opus. More than any other movie, this may be the one you’re looking for.

2: Taxi Driver (Scorsese, 1976). Scorsese is a giant in the New Hollywood cinema movement, possibly surpassing Coppola. This guy has managed to remain relevant form more decades than any other director I can think of, and Taxi Driver is definitely one of his most important and seminal works. A must see.

3: Blue Velvet (Lynch, 1986). This one is a doozy. I first saw this when I was in Junior High, and holy mackerel, it blew me away. David Lynch studied abstract expressionistic painting in college, and his training shows in a lot of his films. It can be seen in his big screen debut Eraserhead (1977), his tour de force Mulholland Drive, and even his television masterpiece Twin Peaks (1990). Blue Velvet, though experimental, remains accessible and even has a coherent plot. 

4. Naked Lunch (Cronenberg, 1991). Yep! This is where I got my user name.  The Fly (1986) may be Cronenberg’s best known film, but Naked Lunch is probably his best, and definitely has life changing potential. Unlike Kubrick, Scorsese, and Lynch who are all cinema auteurs, Cronenberg is more what you’d call a vulgar auteur, that is an artist who can split the difference between gravitas and popcorn sensibilities.

5: Hausu (Obayashi, 1977). I really should have mentioned this one in the top three, but here we are at number 5. Hausu is an experience. Seriously, it is possibly the most visually spellbinding motion picture ever made. After the enormous success of Jaws (Spielberg, 1977), the Japanese production company Toho (responsible for Godzilla) wanted a Jaws of their own. They tapped commercial director Nobuhiko Obayashi for the gig, who in turn asked his five year old daughter for story ideas. The result was a haunted house movie that feels like a high speed Lisa Frank fever dream. 

6: The Boxers Omen (Kuei, 1983). This one is rowdy. I mean mean really really rowdy. No movie can match Hausu in terms of psychedelic visual overload, but this one tries. It teeters schizophrenically between slapstick puppet show and grindhouse exploitation. Imagine watching a Bruce Lee flick, but not knowing what planet you’d woken up on. But be warned, more than any others on this list, this one gets a little intense. 

7: The Peanut Butter Solution (Rubbo, 1985). This is my personal favorite movie of all time, and I would have opened with this, but it’s a kids movie and I didn’t want you to think I was throwing you a softball just because you were 14. That being said, this one is a gem. And don’t let the fact that it’s a children’s film fool you. It was directed by a man with a background in radical political documentaries and shadow directed by Vojtěch Jasný who was an important member of the Czech New Wave. Like Hausu, this one was co-written by the directors child. The script began as a stream of consciousness bed time story that Rubbo made up with his son each night, and it shows. Just when you think you know where this movie is headed, you don’t. This flick is dreamy, dreamy, dreamy.

8: The Devils (Russell, 1971). This is the best movie about nuns that will ever be made. Period. Ken Russell is a visionary gift from another planet. Great sets, brilliant acting, marvelous script, and the greatest crocodile cameo in cinema history. 

9: Natural Born Killers (Stone, 1994). Oliver Stone is as irregular and unpredictable as they come. He wrote the screenplay for Scarface (DePalma, 1983) 🥳, but he also directed World Trade Center (2006) 🤨. Natural Born Killers was the movie he was sent to this planet to make. Watching it is like following the story of Bonnie and Clyde purely through channel surfing. It’s cinema, it’s television, it’s… it’s own thing. A wholly singular experience. AND it’s got an amazing soundtrack co-produced by none other that Trent Reznor and Dr. Dre. 

10: Starship Troopers (Verhoeven, 1997). Paul Verhoeven is another vulgar auteur, arguably an even more blatant example than Cronenberg. This one is a total cineplex film, through and through. People may even balk that it’s making a top ten list. But you asked for life changing and shocking films, and Verhoevens filmography has those in spades. He’s a Dutch director who cut his filmmaking teeth making more “art house” films, but once he got to Hollywood, he banged out an impressive slate of pictures that, despite their obvious mainstream appeal, all had something visceral and beautiful bubbling beneath their surface. Robocop (1987) and Showgirls (1995) could just as easily taken the tenth spot on this list, but I feel Starship Troopers is probably the best entry point to Verhoevens work there is. It’s screenplay is tighter than Chinatown (Polanski, 1974) or Die Hard (McTiernan, 1988)… yes I said it, fight me… it does a great job of incorporating multimedia storytelling, the humor is solid, and visually stands apart from virtually any other sci-fi I’ve ever seen. 10/10

Instead of watching the most mind blowing movies first,  you should consider watching classics first.   The thing is, there are a lot of great movies that invented an idea, or technique, or plot line.   Since then they have been copied with better CGI or multiple great techniques in the same movie.    

If you watch the current whiz-bang shows first,  then the classics will seem too simple,  too black & white, and will bore you.    If you watch them first they will be exciting and great,  then you will see how they evolved into other great movies.

It's pretty interesting when you look at it.

Back in the 80s and 90s there were (roughly) three types of movies made. The true independent low budget, the AAA tent pole movies, and finally (what I call) the mid tier movie. Star Power but not as big as AAA but not independent either 

This is where Miramax, Touchstone, Cannon and Caroloco sat.

Where there actual role was to experiment and create something risky and different. It made going to the movies diverse.

By the time around I'd say the mid 90s, studios would greenlight flicks and if it didn't make it in box office it would go through the secondary DVD market which was very lucrative especially for quirky smaller pictures with a cult following.

When DVDs and physical media started to dry up and streaming started to trend that secondary market was lost, which has the indirect consequence of placing all the financial burden on box office 

This meant mid tier movies were no longer green lit as you couldn't predict if they would actually make money.  And the over analysis of market data created the template for the perfect cookie cutter 4 quadrant movie. That was expanded upon with the logic if you have the perfect template, then if you give it more money it will return more money. Coupled with this happening around the lightening in a bottle that was the MCU and you had the perfect storm. Spending 200 to 300 million (at that time) returned 1 billion or more.

This also consequentially diminished the importance of the "movie star" (Tom Cruise being one of, if not the last official one).

It worked until it didn't and the cycle repeats. Same way as the big musicals of the 50s and 60s were too expensive and died. And that ushered in new blood such as Spielberg, Coppola, De Palma, and Lucas ... which is way the 80s (imo) was so cinematic.  To be fair, might be somewhat rose colored as this was the era I grew up in.

But that's to say we are starting to see the change, with A24 and Bloomhouse being two of the studios to watch for their knack of finding those current mid tier stories that are connecting with users.

TLDR; Movies have gone from being creative to being content and content never inspires longevity but simply a return to being creative. As that is the heart of Art.

Companies want money, they follow a formula, formula is not accurate because people are not formulaic. Same old problem: Happened in the 60s, so then the 70s had a burst of character driven, interesting films, because the industry acknowledged the problem and gave indie film directors more free reign/power. Now, post covid, production is way down, and companies are focusing more on content creation vs film because that’s where the money is. So film gets demoted to following the formula.

Film studios are no longer interested in taking risks on unique stories and are instead keen on making huge profits. For example, studios are less likely now to produce a $15mil film with the hopes of making that back plus some. It’s no longer enough for studios to just make a profit; they want to make a HUGE profit to appease their shareholders. Let’s say after all is said and done, the studio takes home $30mil in profit off of that one $15mil film, their profit doubling what they spent albeit on a small scale. The film is a success and they go on to make sequels that also become successes. A win, right?

Well that model is largely obsolete now with big studios. They’ve shifted to a “let’s invest $200mil with the hopes of making $400-500mil+ profit” mindset. This is largely what’s led to what you describe - dull, predictable, stale, and creatively-bankrupt projects that all end up looking and feeling the same. They buy into formulaic methods of storytelling that leave us with cookie-cutter movies. Notice all the IP prequels, sequels, and reboots that have been plaguing the film industry for the past decade? It’s because studios are placing their bets on making tons of money off properties that they know were already successful in the past. They’re simply afraid of taking creative risks now and think that throwing mountains of money at something will make it good. Ironically many of these films fail miserably, which leads me to my next point.

The reason big budget films tend to flop more now is because studios prefer dumping money into cheap visual and narrative gimmicks hoping they can make a quick and big ROI rather than telling a good, original story. And when those films inevitably fail due to their lack of creative vision, they become even less inclined to take risks, leading to a downward spiral/self-fulfilling prophecy effect. To bring it back, this is why you’re seeing all these prequels, sequels, and reboots of existing IPs now; studios think they can simply ride off their previous successes, not understanding what made the originals so great to being with: THE STORY. The thing about having a smaller budget is that it forces you to allocate funds more carefully, usually into the writing, which can lead to a more engaging film overall. The perfect recent example of this is with Godzilla Minus One, a film that had a budget of $10-$15mil and ended up making $113mil at the box office, roughly 10 times its budget. Why? Because their focus on writing a compelling narrative carried the film as opposed to an over reliance on CGI and done-to-death film tropes. Not to mention the director is a VFX artist, so he was able to head that department with keen oversight.

There are MANY other factors I could go on and on about, but this in my opinion is the root cause of why modern studio films all have that same, stale look and feel to them. They’re only thinking about how they can potentially make a huge profit instead of telling a good story.

The more you watch, the more your base of knowledge & experience grows making it harder for the next movie to be unique. It happens with music too - everything "new" in my 50s sounds like I've heard it already.

Studios are no longer run by people who are passionate about movies. They're run by business majors whose only passion is eternal 5-15% growth. Since eternal growth is impossible, in order to preserve their jobs, they know to aim any given movie's appeal at the widest part of the market bell curve, which is the middle. PG-13 movies that appeal to the maximum number of people and risk alienating the minimum amount of people is a very safe bet, mitigating the risk of loss. Unfortunately, while risk can lead to horrific disaster, it's also the only way to achieve excellence. But the risk of loss isn't mitigated by the potential for excellence when a reliable return can be extracted from mediocrity. That's why a capitalist-driven arts program of any kind will lean hard into mediocrity by the end of its life cycle, which is where we're nearing, at least in terms of "Hollywood," the institution. That's my take, anyway.

Matt Damon talked about this as it relates to the death of the secondary release market...in that, there used to be a theatrical release, and a studio could project a certain amount of revenue during that run. Months later, there'd be a DVD (or for us Olds, a vhs) release, which would generate further income. These were, for the most part, relatively known figures/projections, and they'd be used to establish a budget. Essentially, his point was that there was more appetite for studios to take on riskier projects, as they knew there'd be at least two  opportunities to make back the investment. With streaming, its less clear on how studios will make money, so they're less likely to invest in something that isn't guaranteed to draw in a theatrical audience.

title: Films everyone adores and you can't help but wonder why on Earth?
author: Arrival_Mission
description:
I just finished watching a film (whose title I won't mention because I don't want to derail my own thread) belonging to a genre I like, with an interesting premise -- a film which has a score of 94% on Rotten Tomatoes, and a 7-something on imdb. I didn't hate it, but I didn't feel anything beside a mild irritation for its fashionably bloated runtime. I was also quite incensed that it has been acclaimed as "immensely original" while it borrows pretty much every trope of its national cinematographic industry.

Are there films that make you wonder if you're asking the right things from a movie?

comments.comment: Star Wars

Doesn't even come close to an episode of the Outer Limits. Let alone 2001.

A stupid  plot, like finding, terraforming and colonizing a planet is easier than terraforming earth to solve the problem, carried by stupid characters, and I don't even want to start on that...

Overall bad writing.

Rotten Tomatoes is tricky, because the rating system is binary. Either the film is fresh, or not fresh. If 100 reviewers think vanilla ice cream is "pretty good", it'll get a 100% rating. But if the flavor is something even a little bit more divisive like pistachio or licorice, even if 80% of the people find it incredible, but 20% don't, it gets a worse rating.

I'm not saying Rotten Tomatoes is always wrong, but the percentage system tends to favor inoffensive and unchallenging films.

title: Watched "Jackie Brown" by Quentin Tarantino—
author: aishikpatra
description:
Finally got around to watching "Jackie Brown", and wow, what an experience! I knew it would be great, being Tarantino, but it honestly exceeded my expectations.

The plot itself is deceptively simple but perfectly layered. Pam Grier plays Jackie, a flight attendant who’s down on her luck and caught in a dangerous game between her boss (a smooth yet menacing gunrunner played by Samuel L. Jackson) and the feds, who want to use her to take him down. What I love is how Jackie’s story unfolds—she’s smart, resourceful, and incredibly resilient, but also feels grounded and real. Watching her navigate the increasingly tense situations, manipulating both sides, had me on the edge of my seat the whole time.

And then there are the supporting characters—Robert Forster’s Max Cherry is a standout, bringing this quiet, unassuming charm that makes his growing connection with Jackie so believable and endearing. De Niro and Bridget Fonda, too, add layers of dark comedy, playing off each other in scenes that are bizarrely hilarious and tense all at once.

Tarantino’s signature style is here, but it’s toned down just enough to let the characters breathe. The pacing is slower, more deliberate, which works beautifully with the heist setup and the twists that follow. Plus, the soundtrack is just brilliant—soulful, nostalgic, and so fitting for every scene.

For me, Jackie Brown deserves way more love and recognition. It’s got all the elements of a classic Tarantino film but with a subtler, more nuanced edge. Absolutely loved it—definitely giving it a 9/10!

comments.comment: It’s been my favorite of his for a long time.
I don’t know whether it is the best Tarantino movie or not, but it’s my favorite.

The Pam Grier season on “the plot thickens” podcast is amazing. And the way she gratefully talks about Tarantino sending her the script, and her not understanding that she was supposed to play the lead. Worth listening to the whole season. https://www.tcm.com/articles/Programming%20Article/021880/tcm-presents-the-plot-thickens
It’s definitely an A M A Z I N G movie!

I’m almost finished with “Rum Punch” by Elmore Leonard - the book Jackie Brown is based on. Some decent backstory in some of the characters and a little extra action, but overall spot on with the movie. I had to read it because Jackie Brown is my favorite of his movies and I had to compare. Glad I did.
